ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Course work also included asynchronously listening to recordings or watching the occasional video.
N/A
We used a small virtual seminar format, with lots of small-group engagement.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: My Russian vocab and speaking skills have benefitted greatly from this course.
Moving my Russian from more fragmented sentences to longer thoughts
Russian reading skills, speaking practice, and history

Completed advanced grammar, developed comfort in reading essays and other documents, developed comfort speaking extemporaneously, learned early 19th-century Russian history and vocabulary, studied Russian pop culture
I developed skills in Russian language as well as 18th century Russian history.
This course helped me pectine more proficient with Russian reading and writing as well as introduced me to Russian history.

Ive been taking Russian at Yale for almost three years, and I felt that this course was the first time I felt I was actually a speaker  even in a small sense  of the language. The course incorporates a lot of knowledge about Russian history and culture, which was very motivating and exciting for me. Overall, the ability to build on previous grammatical and vocabulary knowledge is strong, and I felt like there was a lot of opportunity for group discussion while students focused on their own individual strengths and weaknesses as speakers.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I dont think there are any weaknesses. This was my favorite class. The topics are so interesting. I love how we focus on essential verbs, but also learn less common words.
This course was very involved so there is a lot of work outside of class. The online format works well for this course because of the seminar nature. I dont really have weaknesses for this course.
It is excellently taught in a way that combines in person homework/assignments with class meetings that help engage speaking practice
Strengths: still very engaging while virtual; extremely organized; quick but manageable pace

I liked the course content and the assignments very much. It's useful to do both grammar and Russian history as a two-fold path towards learning language. Presentations were also very interesting and helpful. I would like to see more one-on-one dialogues between students in breakout rooms. I think there will be more overall engagement per person that way.
While true online learning platform made practicing much more difficult, the professor was a highlight of the course.

I really enjoyed this course, and would say its definitely one of my best semesters of Russian in terms of growth. The Professor is very engaged and receptive, and really cares about balancing the comfort and rigor of the course. The strengths are definitely the focus on Russian culture and history, including the multiple narrative/historical essays we read, and the encouragement in the coursework to read Russian materials like books, poetry, news sources, etc. outside of class. I thought that the time in an intensive class in front of a Zoom camera may have warranted a five-minute break halfway through, but the course was really well-done.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The zoom classes are really engaging, I dont really have any comments.
This was perhaps one of the best online classes I had this semester. It's small size made it extremely engaging and the natural format translates well to online learning

Successful practices included: live discussion and cold-calling for answers to reading questions
Practices that could've been improved: maybe using the annotate function on Zoom could have increased participation
I had no issues with online learning.
I think the lecture aspects of this course were incredible thanks to Constantine, but it was difficult to practice a language over zoom.

The course is remarkably similar to how it would have been taught in person, and Prof. Muravnik is quite skilled at using Zoom features. I actually found that the format was helpful for me to become more comfortable speaking spontaneously and having access to resources during the class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. This has been my favorite class I have taken at Yale.
Absolutely, Constantine is a great professor. The course is really challenging and has a big workload but it will push you to improve your Russian.
Yes, if they are interested in a strong understanding of the language, then absolutely

Absolutelyusing the essays on Russian history as a foundation for practicing speaking more at length and reading was smart. While the grammar components were sometimes fast-paced, there was always space during the class for review and clarification.
Yes, I would definitely recommend it to students that want to learn Russian.
Yes- it is a great course for anyone dedicated to Russian.
